This afternoon, Governor Wolf has announced that schools will remain closed for two additional weeks, with the Department of Education adding that the closures will last until at least April 6. Previously, he had shut them until March 30. The Department of Education said that, once schools are safe to open, administrators and teachers will have two days to prepare before students return on the third day.

The District’s administrative team will meet tomorrow morning to plan how to provide additional learning activities during this extended school closure. As these activities become available, we will communicate them to you.

Please follow all guidance from the Center for Disease Control, the Pennsylvania Department of Health, and the Governor to keep yourself and others safe.

HELP NEEDED!

One of our families in the District suffered a devastating loss early this morning when their home caught on fire. Luckily, no one was injured but they have lost everything. With the family's permission, we are seeking assistance to help them. There are six children ranging from second 2nd to 12th grade. We will be collecting clothing and household items for them. The two youngest children would wear about a 12-14, one girl in second grade and one boy in fourth grade. The middle school children, one boy/one girl, are wearing teen/adult smalls and the older girls, mom and dad would need large/x-large. Any items collected that the family won't be using will be donated to local charities. Items may be dropped off at the High School or District Office at Linntown starting on Tuesday. One of the things that we love most about our schools and community is the way we come together to help others in need. Thank you in advance for your support.

SECURITY INCIDENT: We received a call from local law enforcement shortly after 1:00 AM this morning notifying us that a student in Lewisburg received a text message indicating that schools would be closed on January 29 due to a bomb threat. The text originated from a student in the Watsontown Area. Although the district did not receive a direct bomb threat, school administrators and staff coordinated with local law enforcement to conduct a sweep of each school building early this morning out of an abundance of caution. The buildings were cleared at approximately 5:30 AM and schools will be operating on their normal schedule.

We later learned that the State Police were able to locate the student that sent the text message and determined that it was a hoax. We are grateful for the quick response of our local law enforcement agencies, school leaders, and staff in an effort to keep our students and staff safe.
